Reviews.Title: appreciable little workhorse
Reviews.Author: YSC
Reviews.Content: Pros: good build quality, decent lens, quiet zoom motor, uses NiMH AA, small size for AA battery cameras, large screen with decent resolution, fast lens at f2.9, slightly wider than average 32mm lens, many fool-proof features, auto scene selection (very nice for "dummies"), panoramic mode that works well, simple to use, very portable, long battery life.Cons: battery meter fluctuates in accurate response to the NiMH voltage, and has the unintended effect of making the "dummy" user nervous. Image is highly compressed and shows in smeared up details. ISO higher than 400 are very noisy with flattened colors and details, though higher iso are often selected automatically to prevent blur (which is understandable from an average consumer point of view). Video files are too big for the resolution relative to even the average, can use better compression methods. No orientation sensor. Without face detection only center point AF is available.Notes: Got this camera for my dad, who can't ever figure out how to operate anything other than the shutter button. The automatic scene selection was the reason why I got this, along with the ability to use rechargeable AA and its small size (smallest among the AA cameras?).The automatic scene selection works very well. It actively detects lighting, faces, and subject distance (thus uses more battery power as it continuously focuses and meters the scene); it then uses the combination of these information to determine if it's portrait, backlight, macro, landscape, night modes, etc. Scenes are manually selectable too, especially ones that are not auto-detectable (e.g. long shutter requires tripod, and wouldn't be selected automatically since it'll not be fool-proof. ;)). There's a "manual" which lets you configure all the features other than shutter speed and aperture, as well as a regular "auto" mode.Build quality on the two cameras we got were excellent. It's a budget camera so it was made of a piano-like finish silver plastic with chrome trims. It felt solid in the hand with no squeaks and loose bits, and all buttons were tight and responsive, especially the shutter button. The zoom motor was very smooth and quiet (can't say that about many of the canons), and the LCD screen was big enough and had sufficient resolution and brightness to look satisfactory.Images, even at the highest resolution and best quality show significant compression artifacts (smeared details and loss of color depth). Higher ISO than 400 shows significant noise. Lens is probably on the soft side though I haven't really done serious comparisons, but nothing extraordinary for this price level. The field resolution is fairly even though, and corner blurriness didn't bleed too much into the image, which is good. Lens is fairly quick at f2.9, impressive for this size camera, and also slightly wide at 32mm equivalent. Video files seems bigger than average: a 640x480 movie can only record for about 30 minutes on a 8gb card; the quality of the videos didn't seem to justify the very large size. Images at lower ISO have decent color reproduction, even at long shutter speeds (tripod night scene mode). The longest shutter time I was able to get out of this thing is 4", but am not sure if it can go longer.Battery life is excellent: we used it heavily (flash photos, active scene selection, lots of video tests) for quite a bit more than 2 hours (i don't want to say 3 hours but it's close if not more) before the two Eneloops (around 2000mA each) ran out completely. DO get rechargeable low discharge NiMH batteries, as alkalines are not meant for high current draw of digital cameras and will be wasted in a short order. The battery meter fluctuates quite a bit though, as it seems to depend directly on the instant voltage of the battery; e.g. it will dip slightly after a flash photo, but recover over time as the battery chemistry catches up and shows full again in seconds/minutes. It did get my dad a little nervous though; but to me it is better than some other brands who don't even show the battery meter at all until nearly depleted (e.g. canon A series), probably due to the difficulty in tracking the NiMH voltage?Fuji made a point of making this camera easy to use and fool-proof. The auto scene selection is a testament of that, and I appreciate this feature very much, particularly for elderly or people who aren't tech savvy and don't know when to use fill flash/slow shutter/slow sync, etc. Fuji seems to automatically manage most situations pretty well. While the auto scene mode's hiking up ISOs in low light situations isn't my cup of tea (done at the sacrifice of image quality) it does make sense in that it will at least GET the image (and not some blur). It's thoughtful in trying to satisfy the less knowledgeable users, even at slight sacrifice in absolute quality.It's a good camera for "dummies"--with its innovative auto scene selection feature, compact size, universally available and long lasting batteries-- if you can tolerate the apparently mediocre image quality. At this price range you probably shouldn't expect much better. Portability, build quality, ease of use, and affordability are all covered very well by this little package. I think it's worth a look if you are in for an economical pocket camera with decent performance and true point-and-shoot ease.

Reviews.Title: Great Buy
Reviews.Author: J. Wilson
Reviews.Content: It is cheap, makes good photos, and is easy to use. Wah lah.. perfect gift for a mother in law who is not so savy with new technology and controlling SLR's so to speak. So at the end of the day it was well worth the buy and has held up well!

Reviews.Title: Great for the non-professional
Reviews.Author: K. Kaderka
Reviews.Content: Good quality, easy to use, professional photographer rates it great for the non-professional who wants to click and shoot, and get good close up shots.

Reviews.Title: Wonderful Camera
Reviews.Author: Ramon Enrique Berliza Yorro
Reviews.Content: At first i though i was buying a simple camera, after i received i realized it was a very good deal and i am very happy with my camera. the price was nice and the quality is amazing.

Reviews.Title: A good camera for non-techies.
Reviews.Author: K. Fischer
Reviews.Content: This little camera is great for me. It is easy to use and connect for uploading. The battery feature is appealing for me, meaning I don't have to rely on an electrical outlet. I always keep a couple batteries with me for back up emergency. I am very happy with the picture quality for my needs.

Reviews.Title: Great for newbies
Reviews.Author: A. Simon
Reviews.Content: This was my first camera. If you want to learn about basic digital cameras or you just take pictures of your vacations, I would recommend this Finepix. This is a good start camera.It's affordable, cheap & does what it's worth. There are lots of photo quality options, each one listing how many photo frames are left, so you know how many photos to take with that specific quality.Then you also have various shooting modes, including: Automatic, Manual, Scene Recognition (which is ok, but not great), Landscape, Panorama, Night Mode and plenty more. Some of these options produce clearer photos than others, like Text mode for example (for seeing clearer text/letters). It's VERY clear & blurs the background a bit just to snap whats in front of the lens. Great effect. The Sport mode is the same; great for snapping pics when there's movement. I haven't had the best experience with the Night Mode & I was never really satisfied with any photos that I took at night. But it's still ok; again, this is not a professional camera and it's only 10.2 mp.You can also record videos with this camera. For High Quality shooting, you can record clearer videos but will have shorter recording time and with regular quality shooting, you can record longer videos but with lesser quality.I can't comment on the zoom, because barely used it.Included in packaging is a USB cord and Disc software for uploading photos. But the software sucks in my opinion & it slows down my computer. I prefer Adobe album to upload photos to my computer.AA batteries are needed. I would recommend rechargeable/NiMH batteries. Alkaline batteries will work, but won't last as long.

Reviews.Title: Good, but NOT great camera
Reviews.Author: Tujuana Woods "Lady T"
Reviews.Content: Good camera. Do I like it better than my old Kodak EasyShare? - NO. The picture quality is just okay especially for this camera to be 10MP. My old Kodak EasyShare was only 5MP and the picture quality was much better. Am I sorry I purchased it? - No, not at all. I like the ease of use and how light weight it is. It's a good camera. I hope it lasts longer than the Kodak EasyShares which only has a lifespan of about 2 to 3 years.

Reviews.Title: Perfect gift for the starter
Reviews.Author: Luis Amezquita Martinez "Danyco"
Reviews.Content: I choosed this camera for the easy of use stated on some reviews. It was a gift for my wife these Christmas and I'm very satisfied that the unit is so easy to use, just put the batteries, the sd card and you are ready to take photos. I love it.

Reviews.Title: fun camera
Reviews.Author: Joann J. Aldred "book lover"
Reviews.Content: bought this camera as a gift for my daughter. she said its the best present i ever gave her.

Reviews.Title: Zoom Lens Breaks Quickly/Poor Warranty Service
Reviews.Author: Michael Knudstrup
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera Thanksgiving of 2009.  I shot around 400 pictures with it.  Slowly but surely the zoom lens stopped working.  I went to a lot of trouble to ship it to FujiFilm.  They found a few specks of sand in it and said that voided the warranty.  I took good care of this camera and have to strongly disagree with the result I got from the company.  I think they're just looking for reasons to not replace the camera.  Big disappointment.  I would not recommend this camera at all.

Reviews.Title: Don't waste your money
Reviews.Author: Horsegal JPJ
Reviews.Content: The A170 I that got from my dad, who bought it several years ago (2009?), does not indicate anywhere that it is a "Finepix" but it looks exactly the same as the photo of the camera here (including specs below lens). I just returned from a trip to Arizona, where I used this camera for the first time. It is terrible. It's nice and easy to use, compact, etc., but it takes terrible, low quality photos. It does not focus well, no matter how careful I was, and it can not handle pretty much any light conditions, like with contrast, brightness, low-light conditions, etc. My photos are pretty, um, crummy in quality. This camera does not capture detail, such as texture, etc. My much older Canon SureShot, only 6MP, takes MUCH better photos. Wish I'd brought that instead. Having the greater MP does not guarantee better photos. It's the quality of the lens that counts. This camera has nothing going for it, other than ease of use. I would recommend that it would be fine for, say, an 8-year-old who wants to take photos of her birthday party or whatever. I shouldn't assume that the newer (Finepix) version of the A170 is not better, if it even is a different version; but personally, I wouldn't take the chance. A traveling companion also had a (different and newer) Fuji, and he simply stopped using it, using his iPhone instead. That took better photos than what I was getting. If you're still considering getting it, since other reviewers here seem to like it, I recommend doing more research and, probably, spending more money. I myself would never buy a Fuji.

Reviews.Title: Solid camera but not for extreme conditions.
Reviews.Author: dan "there is more than one way to skin a cat"
Reviews.Content: Solid Camera. Awesome that it runs off 2 AAs. Decent camera for the price. Don't expect insane options since this is a fairly cheap (in terms of price) camera.I also traveled to Harbin, China, where the temps were around -25 C or -15 F in the daytime, and the camera would not function or open after about 15 minutes in this weather. However this is extremely cold weather so I am not sure many digital cameras would work. I was able to use  my iphone4 to take some pictures when that happened.If you use the wrong type of batteries, this camera will eat right through them.That is all.

Reviews.Title: no rechargeable battery and no recharger
Reviews.Author: A. Ramos
Reviews.Content: "BUYER BEWARE" this camera comes with no rechargeable batteries and no battery recharger. I wish that had made that clear in the description.

Reviews.Title: Can't really tell you how they are.
Reviews.Author: EJW
Reviews.Content: I bought two of these as gifts for a couple of children.  I really couldn't tell you how they are working out for them.  Nobody has said anything about them not working, so I assume they are doing fine.

ProductInfo.Features:
10-megapixel resolution
3x optical zoom
SR Auto Mode; automatically recognizes 6 different scene types
Panorama mode
Capture images to SD/SDHC memory cards (not included); powered by AA batteries (included)
ProductInfo.Name: Fujifilm Finepix A170 10.2MP Digital Camera with 3x Optical Zoom and 2.7 inch LCD
